questions.text: A 60-year-old man had the below ECG tracing recorded at his routine physical examination. What is probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This the ECG showing incomplete heart block. In first-degree heart block, all the atrial impulses reach the ventricles but the PR interval is abnormally long. In second-degree heart block, not all atrial impulses are conducted to the ventricles. Third degree heart block that is complete heart block.

Reference: Ganong Physiology, 25th ed, 528

questions.text: Calculate ejection fraction from picture below?
questions.solution:
This is the pressure-volume loop, DAB diastole, BCD systole

EDV-150 ml (point B), ESV-50 ml (point A), SV = EDV-ESV = 100 ml

EF = SV/EDV *100 = 100/150 * 100 = 66.66 %

Reference: Ganong Physiology, 25th ed, 548

questions.text: The following EEG depicts which sleep stage;
questions.solution:
The high-amplitude slow waves seen in the EEG during sleep are periodically replaced by rapid, low-voltage EEG activity, which resembles that seen in the awake, aroused state and in stage 1 sleep. For this reason, REM sleep is also called paradoxical sleep

Reference: Ganong Physiology, 25th ed, 274

questions.text: Name the interval/segment?
questions.solution:
ST segment is end of s wave to onset of T wave, ST interval is end of s wave to end of T wave (QT interval-GRS complex/interval)

Reference: Ganong Physiology, 25th ed, 524-525

questions.text: On changing position from lying down to standing position, there is a drop in 10 mmHg. Immediately he recovered by 8 mmHg leaving behind 2 mmHg.Calculate the gain for baroreceptor system for the control of BP?
questions.solution:
Gain = correction/error = 8/2 = 4

Reference: Guyton physiology 14th ed, pg 8-9

questions.text: Compared with the ICF, the ECF has _____ sodium ion concentration, ______ potassium ion concentration, ______ chloride ion concentration, and ______ phosphate ion concentration
questions.solution:
Na, Cl- higher in ECF; K+, PO4 higher in ICF

Reference: Guyton physiology 14th ed, pg 3-4

questions.text: Arrange following blood constitutes in correct order from above downward as they are present in the wintrobe's tube after centrifugation
questions.solution: They are settled according to weight/volume

questions.text: An electrocardiogram is a graphic illustration of ____________
questions.solution: ECG recording electrical activities while echocardiography recording mechanical activity

questions.text: During the second trimester of pregnancy, where is the predominant site of RBC production?
questions.solution:
Liver is primary site of hemopoiesis during second semester of pregnancy.

Reference: G K Pal physiology 1st ed, pg 78-79

questions.text: Nerve fiber 'x' is stimulated and action potential propagated further. What will be safety factor for propagation?
questions.solution:
Safety factor for propagation must be more than 1 for propagation of impulse. Safety factor for propagation = maximum potential/Threshold potential

Reference: Guyton physiology 14th ed, pg 72

questions.text: Most of the cells composed of.(Choose correct order highest to lowest)
questions.solution:
In the average young adult male, 18% of the body weight is protein and related substances, 7% is mineral, and 15% is fat. The remaining 60% is water

Reference: Ganong Physiology, 25th ed, 3-5

questions.text: In ECG, segment denotes.....
questions.solution:
Interval shows duration and segment shows voltage, A segment refers to a part of the ECG where the tracing is expected to be relatively flat and is measured in terms of voltage on vertical scale. Intervals indicates the time and measures in seconds on horizontal scale.

Reference: Johnson Essential medical Physiology, 3rd ed, 190-191

questions.text: As per weibel's model, total no. of tubing in single lung at the 4th generation?
questions.solution:
Weibel's model denoted as No. of generation based on branching. In weibel's model of lungs, a total 23 generations are there. 1-16 is conductive zone and 17-23 is respiratory zone

Formula is 2n, where n = no. of generation so here 24 = 16 in single lung

Reference: G K Pal physiology 1st ed, pg 881-883

questions.text: The amount of CO2 transported by Bicarbonate form (in ml %)?
questions.solution:
70% CO2 transported in bicarbonate form so 70% of total 4 ml% is 2.8 ml%

Forms by which CO2 is transported: 70 % as HCO3- (chemical), 23 % with Hb (carbamino compounds) 7 % in dissolved form

Reference: G K Pal physiology 1st ed, pg 928-930

questions.text: What will be the SO2 (percentage saturation of O2) when Po2 is 40 mmHg?
questions.solution:
At Po2 o - 0%, Po2 100 - 98%, po2 26 - 50% and Po2-40 its 75% (that is in mixed blood - venous blood)

Reference: G K Pal physiology 1st ed, pg 922-928

questions.text: In normal circumstances, What will be the blood flow to carotid body in ml/min?
questions.solution:
Carotid body (chemoreceptors present in it - sensing the dissolved O2) has highest blood flow in terms of per 100 gm of tissue

The blood flow in each 2 mg carotid body is about 0.04 mL/min, or 2000mL/100 g of tissue/min compared with a blood flow of 54 mL or 420 mL per 100 g/min in the brain and kidneys, respectively.

Because the blood flow per unit of tissue is so enormous, the O2 needs of the cells can be met largely by dissolved O2 alone. Therefore, the receptors are not stimulated in conditions such as anemia or carbon monoxide poisoning, in which the amount of dissolved O2 in the blood reaching the receptors is generally normal, even though the combined O2 in the blood is markedly decreased.

Reference: Ganong Physiology, 25th ed, 659

choices.text: ventricular myocytes with long action potentials

questions.text: In ECG, The U wave is an inconstant finding that may be due to..
questions.solution:
The U wave normally not present in normal ECG, it is mostly due to the Purkinje fiber repolarization but also present due to ventricular myocytes with long action potentials, or electrolyte imbalances.

Reference: Ganong Physiology, 25th ed, 522

questions.text: In ECG, the calculated axis falls to the left of -30°, said to be present__________
questions.solution:
The normal direction of the mean QRS vector is generally said to be −30 to +110° on the coordinate system shown in Figure 29-8. Left or right axis deviation is said to be present if the calculated axis falls to the left of -30° or to the right of +110°, respectively

Reference: Ganong Physiology, 25th ed, 525-526

questions.text: Coughing begins with a deep inspiration followed by forced expiration against a closed glottis. This increases the intrapleural pressure to ____ mm Hg.
questions.solution: Coughing begins with a deep inspiration followed by forced expiration against a closed glottis. This increases the intrapleural pressure to 100 mm Hg or more

questions.text: In CNS, electrical synapse present in....
questions.solution:
Most of synapse present in CNS is chemical type but few places electrical synapses also present.


In CNS, only at three site where electrical synapse is present. Lateral vestibular nucleus, cerebral cortex and hippocampus

Reference: G K Pal physiology 1st ed, pg 981-985

questions.text: In muscle spindle, Nuclear bag fibers innervated by......
questions.solution:
There are two types of nuclear bag fibers - static and dynamic. innervated by γ-motor (static and dynamic), Ia and II fibers - sensory supply

Reference: Ganong Physiology, 25th ed, 229-232

questions.text: The term "vanilloid" refers to a group of substances related structurally and pharmacologically to:
questions.solution:
Know the primary neurotransmitters involved in modulation of pain.

questions.text: The superior colliculus is involved in _______
questions.solution: reflexive responses to auditory stimuli - inferior colliculus; reflexive responses to visual stimuli superior colliculus; upper limb flexion red nucleus

questions.text: Number of thalamus and Hypothalamus in human;
questions.solution: Two thalamus (sensory relay center all sensations relay first in thalamus except smell sensation)) and one hypothalamus (midline structure and present just beneath the thalamus), hypothalamus is midline structure

questions.text: Which of the following is Striking feature in Parkinson disease?
questions.solution:
Parkinson disease results from the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia niagra pars compacta; fibers to the putamen are most severely affected It has both hypokinetic and hyperkinetic features. The hypokinetic features are akinesia and bradykinesia, and the hyperkinetic features are cogwheel rigidity and tremor at rest. The absence of motor activity and the difficulty in initiating voluntary movements are striking.

Reference: Ganong Physiology, 25th ed, 245-248

questions.text: Most of the Abnormalities occurs due to lesions in cerebellum on.........
questions.solution: In cerebrum its contralateral and for cerebellum its Ipsilateral

questions.text: How long should Iron therapy continue after restoration of normal hematologic values?
questions.solution:
Iron therapy should continue for 36 months after restoration of normal hematologic values to replenish iron stores.

Reference: CMDT 2021

questions.text: No. of Spermatid form from single spermatogonia?
questions.solution:
In humans, it takes an average of 74 Days.

The estimated number of spermatid formed from single spermatogonia is 512

From one spermatogonia or primitive germ cell forms 512 spermatid that is finally converted to 512 spermatozoa and this is reason why sperm count in millions

questions.text: Approximate number of mature ovum released from both ovaries during reproductive period.
questions.solution: Reproductive age group of female is from 15-45 years so 12/year is around 360, plus some times more than one ovum is released and extra 5 years is in frequent ovulation so answer is B

questions.text: The nutritive medium for the ejaculated sperms is given by?
questions.solution: During their passage through the female reproductive tract, the seminal plasma provides a nutritive and defensive medium for the spermatozoa

questions.text: Which of these facilitates transport of fructose in the jejunum and Into the sperm?
questions.solution:
GLUT 1 & 3 : Basal glucose uptake in the placenta, brain, RBC, colon, kidney and other organs

GLUT 5: Facilitates transport of fructose in the jejunum and into the sperm

GLUT 7: Increases transport of glucose 6-phosphate into the endoplasmic reticulum in hepatic and other tissues

Reference: G K Pal physiology, 2nd ed, Pg. 535

questions.text: What is the effect of Vit D3?
questions.solution:
Vit D3 acts on Kidney, Bone and Intestine and increases calcium and phosphate level in the blood.

Reference: G K Pal physiology, 2nd ed, Pg. 563

questions.text: Blood testis barrier (BTB), formed by which of these cell(s)?
questions.solution:
The tight junctions between Sertoli cells are too tight, they do not allow substances from interstitial space and blood to pass through them except steroids and few proteins. Thus, tight junction between Sertoli cells near the basal lamina forms the blood-testis barrier (BTB).

Reference: G K Pal physiology, 2nd ed, Pg. 591

questions.text: Maximum amount of water reabsorbed from __________
questions.solution:
Water get reabsorbed 65% from PCT, 15% from loop of Henle, 5% from DCT and 15% CD.

Reference: G K Pal physiology, 2nd ed, Pg. 695

questions.text: In adult female, calculate the amount of O2 (ml/dl) carried by Hb?
questions.solution:
The whole blood of men contains an average of 15 g hemoglobin/100 ml; for women, it contains an average of 14 g hemoglobin/100 ml.

Each gram of hemoglobin can combine with 1.34 ml of oxygen if the hemoglobin is 100% saturated. Therefore, in the average man, a maximum of about 20 ml of oxygen can be carried in combination with hemoglobin in each 100 ml of blood, and in woman 19 ml of oxygen can be carried.

Reference: Guyton physiology; 14th ed; Pg. no. 439

questions.text: A person at an upright position standing to bend over at the trunk. What type of muscular contraction is occurring in the trunk extensors?
questions.solution:
Eccentric is the best answer - that is option 'B'

Because in trunk flexion (as trunk is bend), extensors will not go under isometric contraction, they should go in isotonic contraction and as extensors are antagonists to flexors so eccentric contraction should be done

in concentric muscle contraction there is shorten of muscle so it is not the answer

Isometric option is not suitable here as bending of trunk length of muscle being change. Extensor not active - this option is also not the answer as extensor is active then the bending of the trunk is possible.

Active lengthening of muscle is must for flexing the trunk.

questions.text: The average healthy adult male human has about 45L of fluid. How much of that fluid is in plasma?
questions.solution:
Human total amount of body fluids is about 60% of total body weight.

Here in this question total fluid is 45 liters out of this 2/3 part present in intracellular fluid and 1/3 part present in extra cellular fluid

Plasma is part of extra cellular fluid.

Total is 45 liters, as discussed, 1/3 fluid present in ECF means total 15 liters present in Extra cellular compartments.

Plasma is part of extra cellular compartments and plasma 1/4 of extra cellular fluid compartments. Therefore, total about of fluids present in plasma is about 3.75 liters. Here out of 4 options the correct answer is option A is 3L.

Reference: Ganong Physiology, 25th ed, 3-5

questions.text: A 30-year-old psychotic man has chronic fatigue for 6 months. He has a normal appetite but has refused to eat vegetables for 1.5 year because he hears voices saying that vegetables are poisoned. His physical and neurological examinations are normal. His hemoglobin level is 9.0 g/dl, his leukocyte count is 10,000/μl3, and his MCV is 124. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is anemic; Hg levels are <14 g/dl. The WBC count is normal, suggesting normal bone marrow. His RBCs are considerably larger than normal (normal MCV = 90). His lack of vegetable consumption suggests either a vitamin B12 or folic acid deficiency. However, the body has sufficient stores of vitamin B12 to last 4 to 5 years, so he does not appear to have vitamin B12 deficiency. The body only stores folic acid for 3 to 6 months, so not eating vegetables for 1 year would result in a folic acid deficiency.

Reference: Guyton physiology 14th ed, pg 439-448

questions.text: A patient presents to your office complaining of extreme fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion that has gradually worsened during the past 2 weeks. Physical examination reveals a well-nourished woman who appears comfortable but somewhat short of breath. Her vital signs include a pulse of 120/min, a respiratory rate of 20/min, and blood pressure of 122/70 mmHg. When she stands up, her pulse increases to 150 and her blood pressure falls to 80/50. Her hematologic values are as follows: Hb, 7 g/dl; Hct, 20%; RBC count, 2 * 106/&mul;and platelet count, 400,000/&mul. On a peripheral smear, her RBCs are microcytic and hypochromic. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The blood cell count values show that the patient is anemic. Her bone marrow is functioning and she has a normal platelet count, but she is generating a decreased number of abnormal RBCs. The microcytic (small), hypochromic (decreased intracellular hemoglobin) RBCs are a classic finding of iron deficiency anemia. If she had renal failure, she would be anemic with normal RBCs. People with sickle cell anemia have misshapen RBCs. Megaloblastic anemia is characterized by macrocytic (large) RBCs.

Reference: Guyton physiology 14th ed, pg 439-448

choices.text: The average concentration of hemoglobin in each red cell
The total number of red cells
The variation in red cell size (all the same size vs. some big ones and some little ones)
The percentage of blood volume that is composed of red cells

questions.text: The RDW measures;
questions.solution:
The variation in red cell size (all the same size vs. some big ones and some little ones)

RDW increased in both macrocytic and microcytic anemia.

questions.text: All of the following cell types undergo cell division, EXCEPT;
questions.solution:
Myocyte cell division in the human heart ceases a few weeks after birth. Thereafter, enlargement of the heart is as a result of cell hypertrophy or the laying down of collagen in the extracellular space.

DNA turnover is almost undetectable except in pathologic states.

Approximately 20% of myocytes in the human heart have two nuclei, so that cell separation, rather than mitosis, could bring about a small

Increase in the total cell number.

Reference: Ganong physiology 25th ed

choices.text: Is equal to the potential of ventricular muscle fiber
Can be measured by surface electrodes
Increases as extra cellular K+ increases

questions.text: Resting membrane potential in nerve fiber
questions.solution:
Depends on potassium ion equilibrium, K+ ion is major ion responsible for RMP.

K+ ion is most diffusible ion in excitable tissue under resting condition.

Nernst potential of Cl- ion is closest to the RMP.

Reference: Ganong physiology 25th ed

questions.text: Which of these is not a part of extracellular matrix
questions.solution:
Extracellular matrix proteins are collagen, elastin, fibrillin, fibronectin, laminin and proteoglycans (GAGs) Mn- "Call Ela For Last Prose" Whereas cell adhesion molecules present in cytoplasm or cell membrane include integrins, selectins, cadherins and immunoglobulin family CAMsQ. - Integrins are cell surface adhesion protein that provide linkage between cell outside & inside, between cell- cell and between cell & extracellular matrix.

Reference: G k Pal physiology 1st ed

questions.text: Most diffusible ion across membrane in resting condition
questions.solution:
K+ ion is the most diffusible ion in excitable tissue under resting conditions.

Nernst potential of Cl- ion is closest to the RMP.

Na+ is responsible for action potential in Nerve fibers and muscles

Ca++ is responsible for the action potential in smooth muscle and pacemaker cells of cardiac muscle

questions.text: Myelination in peripheral nervous system is done by _______
questions.solution:
Myelination in central nervous system → Oligodendrocytes.

Myelination in peripheral nervous system → Schwann cell

Reference: G k Pal physiology 1st ed

choices.text: Movement of water across cell membrane
Movement of oxygen across cell membrane
Co-transport of amino acids with sodium

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of active transport?
questions.solution:
Active transport of Na + and K + is one of the major energy-using processes in the body.

The active transport of Na + is coupled to the transport of other substances (secondary active transport).

For example, the luminal membranes of mucosal cells in the small intestine contain a symport that transports glucose into the cell only if Na + binds to the protein and is transported into the cell at the same time.

Reference: G k Pal physiology 1st ed

questions.text: Life span of neonatal RBC?
questions.solution:
Normal life span of RBC is 120 days,

life span of fetal RBC (2 week) megaloblast RBC ( 40 days), spherocyte (10-30 Days)

questions.text: Feed forward type of inhibition seen in
questions.solution:
In feed-forward inhibition, a neuron is connected through two pathways one excitatory and one inhibitory.

For example, in cerebellum the stimulation of Basket cells produces IPSPs (inhibitory postsynaptic potentials) in Purkinje cells.

However, the basket cells and the Purkinje cells are excited by the same parallel-fiber excitatory input.

This arrangement is called feed-forward inhibition and helps to prevent the duration of the excitation produced by any given afferent impulse.

Reference: G k Pal physiology 1st ed

questions.text: True about gap junctions are all, EXCEPT;
questions.solution:
Gap junctions are intercellular connections consist of a pair of hemichannels (connexons) inserted into the membrane of adjacent cells.

Each connexone is made of six identical protein subunits called connexins which enclose a central channel.

When the corresponding connexons of adjacent cell link up end-toend,they form a continuous channel that permits substances to pass through from cell to cell.

At gap junctions, the intercellular space narrows down to 3nm, thereby helping in binding the cells together. o However, their real physiological significance lies in allowing ions to flow through them, i.e. they conduct ionic current.

This enables electrical excitation to spread from cell to cell, as in smooth and cardiac muscles.

The pore size of gap junctions decreases when intracellular Ca' is high or pH is low, both of which are commonly associated with cell damage. Closure of gap junctions in response to these stimuli isolates damaged cells so that the Ca+2 and 1-1+ do not spread from the damaged to normal cells.

Reference: G k Pal physiology 1st ed

questions.text: Gamma globulin are synthesized in.
questions.solution: Liver synthesizes most of the proteins of body except immunoglobulins (gamma globulins), which are synthesized by Plasma cells.
